awd_titl_txt: INSPIRE: Excitonic Quantum Coherence - A Viable Path to Quantum Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This is an INSPIRE grant. Universal quantum computers with the ability to solve problems beyond the capability of present supercomputers have yet to be realized. This interdisciplinary project focuses on whether the assembly of organic dye molecules into complex excitonic networks using DNA self-assembly provides a viable path for the construction of such computers. An exciton is the packet of energy that resides in an organic dye molecule when it is in its excited state. This packet of energy is a quantum mechanical object that exhibits both wave-like and particle-like behavior just as light does. A manifestation of the wave-like behavior of the exciton is its ability to spread out over a dye molecule network so that it resides on multiple chromophores simultaneously. This process is referred to as excitonic quantum coherent energy transfer. A manifestation of the particle-like behavior is that two excitons can collide and scatter off of each other as they spread over a dye molecule network. By exploiting these two behaviors, in principle, dye molecules can be arranged into networks that function as quantum gates and quantum computers. In order for quantum coherent energy transfer to occur, dye molecules must be brought within a few nanometers of each other and, in order to build a quantum gate, dye molecules must be found for which quantum coherence can be maintained over a large dye network. The fundamental issue this research is seeking to address is whether dye molecules of sufficient quality can be found and whether these can be arranged into the complex networks with the close spacing required in order to make a functioning quantum gate and thereby provide a path to scalable universal quantum computation. This research program provides Boise State University students specific educating, training and mentoring in nanophotonics and computational materials science. This experience equips these students to meet the ever evolving and advancing technological needs of both local and national high tech industries and educational and scientific institutions. Combining education, training, and research with outreach, this research will advance the discovery, innovation, and overall knowledge-based prosperity of science and engineering.

Technical Description:
The goal of this research is to develop a new materials system for the assembly of quantum computers in which quantum computation is carried out by a many-exciton quantum walk over a network of dye molecules. The two primary tasks of this research are (1) to identify suitable dye molecules and (2) to determine the means by which these dye molecules, when covalently attached to DNA, can be arranged into the requisite configurations to function as quantum gates. In the first task, dye molecules are identified that, when paired using DNA assembly, exhibit large Davydov splitting and strong exciton-exciton interactions as determined by absorption spectroscopy and differential absorption spectroscopy, respectively. In the second task, how best to covalently attach dye molecules to DNA substrates to form quantum coherently interacting dye networks is established. A fundamental issue addressed by this research is how to effectively perform computation with excitons. The work impacts existing quantum computation research by providing new gate architectures that are robust against dispersion and decoherence and that have faster switching times than existing quantum gates.
The grant is co-funded by the following programs, OIA; EPSCoR; CISE; ENG; and MPS.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Our NSF INSPIRE grant supported key fundamental research related to understanding the unique properties of specific molecular quantum materials. In particular, our Quantum DNA (qDNA) Research Group at Boise State University has pioneered the use of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)-based self-assembly as a method to precisely place molecular dyes (chromophores) with nanometer precision (i.e., DNA templating) into dye aggregates (two or more dyes) to achieve desirable quantum behaviors. Our interdisciplinary, highly collaborative group included faculty, professional staff, undergraduates, and graduate students from a number of disciplines, including materials science and engineering, electrical engineering, chemistry, and physics. For the students, this project provided a broad but also deep education in which they experienced and participated in a project that spans a variety of scientific fields.

When dyes aggregate with nearest neighbor distances of 2 nanometers or less and are excited by an electromagnetic field (e.g., laser pulse), delocalization of excitons can occur. These molecular excitons, or the bound state of an electron and an electron hole, are quasiparticles that transfer energy but not charge. Delocalization is a coherent effect in which the electronically excited states of the aggregated dyes are in quantum superposition (i.e., can be represented as a sum of two or more distinct states) and have a well-defined energy and phase relation to the incident wave. This effect is dependent not only on the distance between dyes but also on their orientation with respect to each other and results ultimately in different geometrical relationships of the dyes and their electric dipoles. These different packing relationships of the dyes exhibit certain types of optical behaviors that manifest as different spectral shifts (i.e., red versus blue, respectively) or spectrally resolved splitting--known as Davydov splitting--of the dye monomer (single dye) excited state. Maintaining aggregate excited states and preventing their dephasing (i.e., maintaining excited-state lifetimes) for a sufficient period of time is a necessary prerequisite to realize and apply these quantum behaviors to applications such as solar energy harvesting and quantum computing.

To control and fine-tune aggregate behaviors and prevent dephasing, our grant enabled us to advance the knowledge and techniques that can facilitate manipulating a dye's structural properties and the location and stability of a dye's configuration within the DNA scaffold and surrounding environment to achieve desired behaviors. For our study materials system, we used the well-known family of cyanine dyes, with a particular focus on the dye Cy5. Because our ability to tune and apply dye aggregate behaviors can occur at room temperature and in a reproducible manner, the potential impact of our study is considerable. By using DNA-templating schemes to organize covalently attached dyes in a variety of ways, our approach is well-positioned to realize quantum devices required for quantum computation and other applications in an efficient and effective manner.

We accomplished our research milestones through an integrated approach involving multiple research teams. We assessed dye and dye aggregate behaviors in different DNA templates, characterized their ensemble optical behaviors via steady-state and ultrafast spectroscopy, advanced methodologies in single molecule characterization techniques, and further explored the underlying theory associated with molecular excitons.

In particular, we developed and implemented a quantum mechanical model that by fitting spectral data extracts the chromophore orientations within the aggregate and key energy states of the aggregate. This in-house created software tool is now being used in support of all of our projects and multiple collaborations. Through laboratory experiments, theoretical modeling using density functional theory (DFT), time-dependent DFT, molecular dynamics, and the in-house modeling studies, we gained fundamental insights on the optical properties of a full suite of cyanine dyes templated to DNA, including understanding the roles of the DNA scaffold, buffer and salt environments, and dye-to-dye proximity and orientation on achieving desirable properties. Through ultrafast time-resolved laser spectroscopy, we revealed that the nonradiative decay mechanism of internal conversion governs aggregate ground-state recovery dynamics. We postulated that eliminating nonradiative decay pathways in the future design of DNA-templated dye aggregates is of critical importance. Finally, we advanced the development of correlated single-molecule dipole imaging and super-resolution microscopy, informed by molecular dynamics modeling, as a powerful new multi-modal imaging approach for the study of dye orientation and positioning on DNA-templated molecular systems.

Our published research findings have spurred interest from the DNA nanotechnology community. In addition, our research has been the impetus for several recent collaborations and follow-on successful proposals. Our approach, though to some degree still nascent, continues to mature and is shifting away from commercial dye surveys and exploring the fundamental molecular properties of DNA-templated dyes and dye aggregates to: (1) a focus on custom dyes with specified properties of interest and their synthesis and (2) identification of design rules, including their theoretical and experimental confirmation, for DNA-scaffolded dye aggregate architectures to support and sustain quantum behaviors leading to excitonic quantum gates and thus quantum computing.

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2021
Modified by: William B Knowlton
